image.altText: A young woman with long blonde hair stands by an Israeli flag

items.synopsis: Nicole's mother Galit was the only Australian to be killed by Hamas on October 7. Now she has returned to the kibbutz where she was murdered. WARNING: Some readers might find the details and images in this story distressing.

title.children: 'They've been in here, in my house, in my room': Daughter of Australian killed by Hamas tries to find closure

image.altText: Australian economist Sean Turnell looking at the camera after an interview

items.synopsis: The economic adviser to ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi was released by the military in a surprise move in 2022. A year on, he reflects on the dark days and having Brad Pitt play him if his new book makes the big screen.

title.children: Sean Turnell spent 650 days in Myanmar jail. He 'constantly dreams' he's still there a year after his release

image.altText: A close up of a sleeping baby with hair as a woman's hand with a gold ring touches the baby's nose.

items.synopsis: New mothers in Australia are expected to be back on their feet quickly after giving  birth. But in many ancient cultures, the first weeks are a precious time to recover and bond with the baby.

title.children: 'We are lucky Athama is here': The first weeks after giving birth are time of healing in some ancient traditions

image.altText: Anthony Albanese shakes hands with Xi Jinping in front of the Australian and Chiense flags in Beijing.

items.synopsis: The itinerary of Anthony Albanese's latest foreign excursions involved some incredible diplomatic U-turns that neatly sum up the dilemma and danger we face in our region, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: Did we win the China trade war, or just move the battleground?

items.synopsis: Politicians and experts call for the end of violence on Australian streets and in the Middle East on Q+A but they can't agree on one panellist's assertion that terrorist group Hamas are not the only problem.

title.children: 'Abhorrent' protests should not be allowed to happen again: Q+A panellists condemn violence in Australia

image.altText: A man in a suit walking

items.synopsis: Brits were shocked when a former prime minister was parachuted back into politics in the role of foreign minister on Monday, but many Australians know this story well, including how it could end.

title.children: This political plot twist shocked Brits, but Australians know it well

image.altText: Buses in Adelaide Street in Brisbane city on January 11, 2021.

items.synopsis: What contribution has privatisation made to the creation of a better, fairer, more harmonious society? Britain's experience with the sale of its water and sewage network suggests not all industries come out on top, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: Britain's 'unbearable' sewerage problem is a warning against privatisation in Australia

image.altText: High density housing with predominantly dark roofs.

items.synopsis: Renters in every Australian capital city are in a worse position than they were before the pandemic, the latest Rental Affordability Index report shows

title.children: Renters in every capital city worse off as housing situation 'crushes your soul'

image.altText: Close up of red and green numbers on ASX board

items.synopsis: The Australian share market is expected to open higher despite Wall Street's struggle to find direction overnight as investors await crucial inflation data that will decide how high US interest rates will climb. Follow live.

title.children: ASX likely to rise, Wall Street fluctuates ahead of US inflation data

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning! I’ll be here to guide you through the latest finance and economic news. The Australian share market is likely to start its day with solid gains, with ASX futures up 0.9%. That’s despite Wall Street’s main stock indexes making very little progress in either direction (ie. flat) as investors await the latest US inflation figures (on Wednesday AEDT). This data will determine whether the US Federal Reserve will keep interest rates elevated, and its timing for a rate cut – which the market is betting will happen next year. Traders have priced in a nearly 86% chance that the Fed will hold interest rates in December, according to the CME Group's FedWatch tool. Meanwhile, the Australian dollar was slightly higher at 63.8 US cents (after rising 0.2% overnight). Later this morning, NAB and Westpac will release their business conditions and consumer sentiment reports, which provides a useful snapshot of how the economy is tracking. However, the key Australian data to look out for is the ABS’s Wage Price Index and Labour Force report (out on Wednesday and Thursday). Oil prices jumped overnight after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) published a monthly report which eased worries about waning demand in the United States and China. Brent crude futures rose 1.2% to $US82.43 a barrel. In its report, OPEC said oil market fundamentals remained strong and blamed speculators for a recent drop in prices. OPEC made a slight increase to its 2023 forecast for global oil demand growth and stuck to its relatively high 2024 prediction.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX likely to open sharply higher, Wall Street trading flat

children.content: Good morning! I’ll be here to guide you through the latest finance and economic news.
The Australian share market is likely to start its day with solid gains, with ASX futures up 0.9%.
That’s despite Wall Street’s main stock indexes making very little progress in either direction (ie. flat) as investors await the latest US inflation figures (on Wednesday AEDT).
This data will determine whether the US Federal Reserve will keep interest rates elevated, and its timing for a rate cut – which the market is betting will happen next year.
Traders have priced in a nearly 86% chance that the Fed will hold interest rates in December, according to the CME Group's FedWatch tool.
Meanwhile, the Australian dollar was slightly higher at 63.8 US cents (after rising 0.2% overnight).
Later this morning, NAB and Westpac will release their business conditions and consumer sentiment reports, which provides a useful snapshot of how the economy is tracking.
However, the key Australian data to look out for is the ABS’s Wage Price Index and Labour Force report (out on Wednesday and Thursday).
Oil prices jumped overnight after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) published a monthly report which eased worries about waning demand in the United States and China.
Brent crude futures rose 1.2% to $US82.43 a barrel.
In its report, OPEC said oil market fundamentals remained strong and blamed speculators for a recent drop in prices.
OPEC made a slight increase to its 2023 forecast for global oil demand growth and stuck to its relatively high 2024 prediction.

image.altText: A middle-aged man and his early 20s son sit at the back of a small motorboat on a lake in front of mountains.

items.synopsis: Renowned polar explorer Dr Geoff Wilson and his 23-year-old son Kitalé are on a two-year mission to make the world fall in love with polar environments, and document their impacts from climate change.

title.children: 'We're graffitiing the Vatican': Inside the epic two-year project to document the degradation of our polar environments

image.altText: Man wearing a black shirt that says 'Burgertory' on the collar, with his arms folded.

image.altText: Lin-Manuel mid-sentence gesturing with his hands in front of him. He looks to the left and wears a grey jacket

image.altText: Dressed in a suit, Chris Minns gives a speech at Labor's campaign launch.

items.synopsis: The NSW Labor Party and politicians including Premier Chris Minns accepted political donations totalling more than $100,000 from lobbyists in the lead-up to the state election, three years after the party argued lobbyists should be banned from donating.

title.children: NSW Labor used to refuse donations from lobbyists. Now they're welcome

image.altText: Donald Trump stands next to his sister Maryanne Trump Barry.

items.synopsis: Maryanne Trump Barry, a retired federal judge and former president Donald Trump's oldest sister, has died at age 86 at her home in New York.

image.altText: A composite image of three men in suits.

items.synopsis: In New Zealand, the Labour Party ministers have just been re-sworn into caretaker government, despite losing the election. Here's why forming government is a little different in Aotearoa.

items.synopsis: How many different types of spiders are there in Australia? New research has scientists estimating that there could be up to 15,000 — including thousands that haven't even been discovered yet.

title.children: Miturgopelma rangerstaceyae is a newly discovered fast-moving, toad-hunting spider. And it's named after a popular kids' TV presenter

image.altText: Shane Cuthbert sits near a Nazi flag.

image.altText: A dump truck emptying a pile of red dirt into a very large mine - there are hills in the background.

image.altText: Lynda George holds a letter and looks at the camera

items.synopsis: Lynda George felt violated when she learnt her personal information was lost to hackers in a data breach. And to make matters worse, it took the hacked company two months to notify her of the issue.

image.altText: A man looks serious.

items.synopsis: Before former ACT greens backbencher Johnathan Davis resigned over sexual misconduct allegations, an internal review by a senior staffer into his alleged conduct revealed Mr Davis was "apparently ... known to have a preference for younger people".

title.children: The ACT Greens conducted an internal review into allegations made against Johnathan Davis. Here's what it revealed

image.altText: A man sits in front of a caravan food truck.

items.synopsis: Two dangerous bushfires, two lucky escapes without any loss of life — but in the wake of two fire events in Tasmania where there was only one way out, the calls are igniting again that people must be given an escape route.

title.children: 'People were trapped': Lack of access roads slammed as Tasmania's fire preparedness questioned

image.altText: people walking outside a store

items.synopsis: Optus says "changes to routing information" after a "routine software upgrade" was behind last week's nationwide outage, affecting 10.2 million Australians and impacting 400,000 businesses.

title.children: Optus says changes after a 'routine software upgrade' to blame for nationwide service outage

image.altText: Two adults stand with a child in a wheelchair.

items.synopsis: Organising a trip to Ballarat was no easy task for this Melbourne family because of 12-year-old Anuli's complex needs. When the outing finally happened, it ended in a way that left them "traumatised".

image.altText: A centrelink sign with on a building with a reflection

items.synopsis: The federal government agrees to all of the recommendations of the Robodebt royal commission, as it reveals investigations have commenced into 16 public servants connected to the scheme.

image.altText: Concept art showing four warships fanning out in open waters.

items.synopsis: The Defence Department has conceded its process for selecting its $45 billion future frigates, closely overseen by Coalition ministers, was "poorly executed".

image.altText: A brunette Pakistani woman, a blonde white woman and a dark brunette black woman wearing superhero outfits stand looking skyward

items.synopsis: Marvel Cinematic Universe's latest movie instalment, The Marvels, has had a disappointing opening weekend at the box office, recording $US47 million in sales in the US — the lowest amount the comic book franchise has recorded to date.

image.altText: A cassowary in the water as waves wash up on shore

items.synopsis: From a distance it resembled a mythic monster but as it came closer in the tropical Queensland waters a stunned onlooker realised the struggling creature was a large bird — and not a seabird.

title.children: Amazed beachgoer videos endangered cassowary emerging from ocean off Far North Queensland
